attributes.name: Use of Potentially Dangerous Function
attributes.description: The product invokes a potentially dangerous function that could introduce a vulnerability if it is used incorrectly, but the function can also be used safely.

attributes.name: 2021 CWE Top 25
attributes.description: By following the Top 25, developers will be able to significantly reduce the number of weaknesses that occur in their software. If a software developer claims to be following the Top 25, then customers can use the weaknesses in this view in order to formulate independent evidence of that claim.

attributes.description: By following the Top 25, developers will be able to significantly reduce the number of weaknesses that occur in their software. If a software developer claims to be following the Top 25, then customers can use the weaknesses in this view in order to formulate independent evidence of that claim.

attributes.name: Uninitialized scalar variable
attributes.description: Use of an uninitialized variable
attributes.local-effect: The variable will contain an arbitrary value left from earlier computations.

attributes.name: Unauthorized modification of data, files, directories or memory
attributes.description: Unauthorized modification of data, files, directories or memory

extra.extended-description: Covers the following technical impacts: Modify memory, Modify application data, Modify files or directories.

attributes.name: Function address comparison
attributes.description: Address of function compared to zero
attributes.local-effect: The function is not called.  This may indicate missing function call arguments.

attributes.name: Quality
attributes.description: Quality type problem

attributes.name: Use of Uninitialized Variable
attributes.description: The code uses a variable that has not been initialized, leading to unpredictable or unintended results.

extra.extended-description: In some languages such as C and C++, stack variables are not initialized by default. They generally contain junk data with the contents of stack memory before the function was invoked. An attacker can sometimes control or read these contents. In other languages or conditions, a variable that is not explicitly initialized can be given a default value that has security implications, depending on the logic of the program. The presence of an uninitialized variable can sometimes indicate a typographic error in the code.

attributes.name: 2011 CWE/SANS Top 25
attributes.description: By following the Top 25, developers will be able to significantly reduce the number of weaknesses that occur in their software. If a software developer claims to be following the Top 25, then customers can use the weaknesses in this view in order to formulate independent evidence of that claim.

attributes.name: Function Call with Incorrectly Specified Arguments
attributes.description: The product calls a function, procedure, or routine with arguments that are not correctly specified, leading to always-incorrect behavior and resultant weaknesses.

extra.extended-description: There are multiple ways in which this weakness can be introduced, including:

attributes.human-readable-cause: This is a legacy issue found on the first known tool run.

attributes.name: Low
attributes.description: Low severity issues

attributes.name: Use of Externally-Controlled Format String
attributes.description: The product uses a function that accepts a format string as an argument, but the format string originates from an external source.

extra.extended-description: When an attacker can modify an externally-controlled format string, this can lead to buffer overflows, denial of service, or data representation problems. It should be noted that in some circumstances, such as internationalization, the set of format strings is externally controlled by design. If the source of these format strings is trusted (e.g. only contained in library files that are only modifiable by the system administrator), then the external control might not itself pose a vulnerability.

attributes.name: 2020 CWE Top 25
attributes.description: By following the Top 25, developers will be able to significantly reduce the number of weaknesses that occur in their software. If a software developer claims to be following the Top 25, then customers can use the weaknesses in this view in order to formulate independent evidence of that claim.

attributes.name: Medium
attributes.description: Medium severity issues

attributes.name: Uninitialized pointer read
attributes.description: Reads an uninitialized pointer or its target
attributes.local-effect: Incorrect values could be read from, or even written to, an arbitrary memory location, causing incorrect computations.

attributes.name: Format string warning
attributes.description: A non-constant string used to construct a format string
attributes.local-effect: A non-constant format string can potentially be exploited by a user to take control of the application.

attributes.human-readable-cause: This is a legacy issue found on the first known tool run.

attributes.name: Denial of service
attributes.description: Contributes to unreliable execution or excess resource consumption.

extra.extended-description: Covers the following technical impacts: DoS: amplification, DoS: crash / exit /restart, DoS: instability, DoS: resource consumption (memory), DoS: resource consumption (other), DoS: resource consumption (CPU).

attributes.human-readable-cause: This is a legacy issue found on the first known tool run.

attributes.name: Injection
attributes.description: Injection flaws, such as SQL, NoSQL, OS, and LDAP injection, occur when untrusted data is sent to an interpreter as part of a command or query. The attacker's hostile data can trick the interpreter into executing unintended commands or accessing data without proper authorization.
